Mainly I moved some of the block comments to inline comments so that they don't show up in the javadocs (the block comments were showing up in the javadocs but only for the first config key, so I don't think it makes much sense to include them there).

@zliu41 @sahilTakiar can you review?
Will take a look today, but tests seem to be failing on Travis CI.
Yes, it seems like a host name resolution issue with `MiniYARNCluster` on Travis. All tests work fine on my machine.

- Added `synchronized` to `TaskState.updateRecordMetrics` and to `TaskState.updateByteMetrics`.
  - The reason is that each method performs get and set semantics (e.g. get the current value of the counter and use it to set the new value).
  - These methods are executed in `AbstractTaskStateTracker.TaskMetricsUpdater` and in `Fork.commitData`
- Added call to `updateRecordMetrics` in `Fork.commitData`
  - The reason is that the record-level and byte-level metrics should be updated one last time after `DataWriter.commit` is invoked to ensure that the metrics are up to date, since the `TaskMetricsUpdater` is only scheduled to run at a specific interval.
- Removed the restriction the `DataWriter.bytesWritten` can only be called after `DataWriter.commit` has been invoked.
  - @liyinan926 do you know why this restriction was added in the first place? I don't see why it needs to be there, and it is useful to get this data from the `DataWriter` on a regular interval so it can be reported while the `Task` is running.
  - In addition, this restriction has never been honored, as it is already being invoked on a scheduled basis in `TaskMetricsUpdater`.
The reason for the restriction is file length won't be available until the file is either flushed or closed.
LGTM.

After spending quite some time on trying to find out a solution to the hostname resolution issue, I gave up. Instead, I just disabled the test that were failing due to the issue as part of a group called `disabledOnTravis`. Updated e9fdc5d.
PR updated.

I think calling `ScheduledFuture.cancel` should be sufficient as I tested it locally and there were no hung threads, but just to be sure I changed the code to shutdown the Thread Pool directly using the `ExecutorUtils.shutdownExecutorService`.
@ibuenros can you take a look?
@sahilTakiar do you have any more comments?

Is there a dire need to get this checked in soon? If not I think we should do a little more design work before making these changes. The PR adds modification functionality only for a `StateStore` that is backed by a `FsStateStore`. I think we should instead take the following approach.
- New interface called `ModifiableStateStore`, with methods like `modify(String storeName, String tableName, String key, Object newValue)`.
- Have `FsStateStore` implement this new interface and move all the code in this PR into this new method.
- Modify the the command line tool changes in this PR to work with `ModifiableStateStore`.
  - This has the advantage that the command line tool is not tied to any specific State Store implementation. Currently, this PR assumes we are interacting with an `FsStateStore`.
Agreed with @sahilTakiar.
Weird that this builds fine on my machine, but fails within travis.  I see the issue and am adding a new variable 'hadoopAwsVersion' to allow overriding (but it defaults to 2.6.0).
@chavdar @zliu41 Moved `dataset` and `datasetFinder` to `gobblin-api`. @ibuenros Can you also take a look on the last commit?

@sahilTakiar can you review?
Seems like this is an intermittent failure.
Seem the build failed due to PR https://github.com/linkedin/gobblin/pull/506 @liyinan926 do we know the root cause?
The weird thing is that have have seen the java7 and java8 builds each succeed in Travis, but not reliably.
The build failed on Hudson because one unit test assumes some ordering that seems not guaranteed on Hudson. I noticed that build on Java 7 has been pretty stable and not so on Java 8.
Do we have any documentation on the testing strategy?
What you mean by testing strategy?
LGTM.

More like what the tests do, how we are using the curator framework, how we are using the MiniDfsCluster, etc. 
- My understanding is that we are using the Curator framework to setup a local Zookeeper instance that Helix connects to, is that correct?
- Why is it necessary to use the Curator framework vs. just mocking HelixManager
- What is MiniDfsCluster needed for? Why is it necessary to use a MiniDfsCluster over a LocalFileSystem.
- Are these all unit tests? Is it possible to have an end-to-end integration tests.

1. The Curator framework is a ZooKeeper client that is easier to use than the official ZooKeeper client library. 
2. The `MiniDFSCluster` was meant to provide a way to get a delegation token. I just realized it's not really necessary since it's essentially the same as `LocalFileSystem` for this, both return `null`, and that's why I need to use mocking. 
3. Yes, these are unit tests. 
4. Yes, I agree we need end-to-end integration tests.

@liyinan926 The build is failing due to gobblin-yarn tests.  These tests work when I run them locally.

**Travis Build**

```
testLaunchJobWithCommitSuccessfulTasksPolicy_1449557062528_0 failed
    java.io.IOException
        at gobblin.runtime.JobLauncherTestHelper$FaultyExtractor.readRecord(JobLauncherTestHelper.java:387)
        at gobblin.runtime.JobLauncherTestHelper$FaultyExtractor.readRecord(JobLauncherTestHelper.java:379)
        at gobblin.instrumented.extractor.InstrumentedExtractorDecorator.readRecordImpl(InstrumentedExtractorDecorator.java:64)
        at gobblin.instrumented.extractor.InstrumentedExtractorBase.readRecord(InstrumentedExtractorBase.java:121)
        at gobblin.instrumented.extractor.InstrumentedExtractorDecorator.readRecord(InstrumentedExtractorDecorator.java:58)
        at gobblin.runtime.Task.run(Task.java:170)
        at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1142)
        at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:617)
        at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)
```
@kadaan the exception log you posted is expected, which is intentionally introduced by the `FaultyExtractor`. I suggest you pull the latest master and merge in the changes.

@liyinan926 As far as I can tell, all the tests work when I run it locally.

I think this is the failure on the Travis box (but it works locally):

```
gobblin.yarn.GobblinYarnAppLauncherTest.setUp FAILED

```

@liyinan926 This is super annoying.  The test I created intentionally mocked the filesystem and file operations.  But in the logs I see this:

```
Gradle test > gobblin.util.ParallelRunnerTest.testMovePath FAILED
    java.io.IOException: java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException: java.io.IOException: /src/file.txt: No such file or directory
        at gobblin.util.ParallelRunner.close(ParallelRunner.java:286)
        at com.google.common.io.Closer.close(Closer.java:214)
        at gobblin.util.ParallelRunnerTest.testMovePath(ParallelRunnerTest.java:195)

        Caused by:
        java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException: java.io.IOException: /src/file.txt: No such file or directory
            at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.report(FutureTask.java:122)
            at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.get(FutureTask.java:192)
            at gobblin.util.ParallelRunner.close(ParallelRunner.java:281)
            ... 2 more

            Caused by:
            java.io.IOException: /src/file.txt: No such file or directory
```

Unfortunately, the stack trace doesn't really help to locate the problem.  All calls on the filesystem class are mocked.

Also, there wasn't an existing renamePath test.  I wonder if it was related to this.

To try to narrow this down I put the new test in it's own project and run the build with travis.  Unfortunately, no repro.

https://github.com/kadaan/hadoop_filesystem_test

Hey, @sahilTakiar, can you take another look d11cd1f?

LGTM

Only comment is why do we need the Curator Framework when we could just mock the `HelixManager` using Mockito? Would making a mock `HelixManager` be hard? The advantage of just using a mock is that we don't have to do things like `Thread.sleep(5000)` in the code to wait for the Helix + ZK interaction to complete.

A `HelixManager` does not allow you to check arbitrary ZooKeeper path. In those tests, I really want to make sure the appropriate ZooKeeper paths get created in real. A mocked `HelixManager` simply won't do the job.
LGTMr
Should we create a wiki page on Github showing the results?
